today iâ€™m honored to share that iâ€™ve joined tendercare as their new creative director!

when my grandma died, i felt lost. after 8 years of being her full-time caregiver, i didnâ€™t know what was next.

then i met shauna, a caregiver for her dad with alzheimerâ€™s, who built tendercare. Itâ€™s a system designed to help families stay organized and find trusted help.

weâ€™re building tools that make life easier for caregivers, starting with the magic magnet + tendercard.

these are free scannable QR codes (one for the fridge, one for your wallet) that give first responders instant access to your loved oneâ€™s emergency info: medications, allergies, conditions, and contacts. plus, your family gets a text alert the moment itâ€™s scanned.

these were built with EMTs, trusted by families, and 100% free.

comment â€œtendercareâ€ and weâ€™ll send you one!

My WHY, continued from post â¤µï¸

Sadly, my parents are gone now, but Iâ€™ve continued to use what I learned caring for them to help me care for other family and friends. The lessons Iâ€™ve learned are invaluable ğŸ™

Caregiving is not for the faint of heart, but you probably know that already.

If I knew then what I know now, I would have saved myself and those around me from exhaustion, panic, anxiety, and heartache.

It this knowledge, wisdom, and experience I want to share with you so you can survive this amazing roller coaster of a ride and be open to scream, cry, laugh, and finally arrive home after the ride of your lifetime âœ¨

So whether youâ€™re just starting out on your caregiving journey, or been in this for years, follow along to be part of a community that UNDERSTANDS you, and is here to support ğŸ’œ

3 powerful ways to become a more self-confident caregiver ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼

Sometimes, we can be bothered by a sense of imposter syndrome because we second guess ourselves or question our abilities â€¦

Here are a few of the tricks I applied when I was knee-deep in crisis mode, keeping everyone else afloat but torturing myself with self-doubt ğŸ˜£

1. Trust yourself 

Listen to your instincts and remind yourself that youâ€™ve already faced and overcome so much. Youâ€™ve aced so many things and any â€˜mistakesâ€™ have only made you stronger and wiser. Keep a list of achievements nearby to look at if you need a reminder.

2. Question your negative thinking

Ask yourself - â€œis that thought TRUE?â€ Take away their power by realising if theyâ€™re not true, why would I act on them? Write them down or say them out loud - they seem much sillier out in the open than they do in your head.

3. Visualise a great outcome

See yourself navigating the situation with confidence and allow yourself to feel proud at this imaginary scenario. Youâ€™ll trick your brain into feeling more prepared and more confident to go forward and face the real-life thing - and have a little smile in the process! 

Save this post for later and let me know if you found this helpful ğŸ’œ
